title: What is leukemia? - Danilo Allegra and Dania Puggioni

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary characteristic of cancer that makes it difficult to cure?

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer occurs in a specific type of cell

options.label: C
options.text: Cancer is a family of over 100 diseases occurring in different types of cells

options.label: D
options.text: Cancer is caused by a single DNA modification

multiple-choice.question: Which type of cancer affects children more than any other type?
What is a stem cell?

options.label: B
options.text: A cell that has specialized into a specific function

options.label: C
options.text: A cell that has great potential but is undeveloped

options.label: D
options.text: A cell that has lost its original function

options.label: B
options.text: Leukemia is caused by just one or two DNA modifications

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To patrol the body and destroy potentially harmful invaders

options.label: D
options.text: To generate new cells and keep up with the body's needs

options.label: A
options.text: The transplanted cells may not be compatible with the patient's cells

options.label: B
options.text: The patient may experience a severe allergic reaction

options.label: C
options.text: The patient may develop a blood clot

options.label: D
options.text: The patient may experience a headache

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a bone marrow transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove leukemic cells from the body

options.label: B
options.text: To replace damaged stem cells with healthy stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the patient's immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of having a large database of bone marrow donors?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the risk of rejection

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the chances of finding a compatible donor

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for more patients to receive successful transplants

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the need for chemotherapy

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the bone marrow is unable to create new blood cells on its own?

options.label: B
options.text: The patient's immune system is strengthened

options.label: C
options.text: The patient requires a bone marrow transplant

multiple-choice.question: Why is antigen compatibility between the donor and recipient important for bone marrow transplantation?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure the transplanted cells are rejected by the patient's immune system

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the transplanted cells from attacking the patient's own cells as foreign bodies

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the risk of rejection

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease the chances of finding a compatible donor

title: Why neutrinos matter - Sílvia Bravo Gallart

multiple-choice.question: What are neutrinos, and where can they be found?

options.label: A
options.text: They are ghost particles flying through matter and can be found everywhere in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a type of star and can be found in the galaxy.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a type of asteroid and can be found in the asteroid belt.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a type of planet and can be found in the solar system.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about neutrinos compared to other particles?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a strong magnetic field.

options.label: B
options.text: They are highly interactive with other matter.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the largest known particles in the universe.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the smallest known particles in the universe, a million times less massive than an electron.

multiple-choice.question: How do neutrinos interact with matter?

options.label: A
options.text: They interact strongly with matter and are easily detectable.

options.label: B
options.text: They interact only with certain types of matter.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not interact with matter at all.

options.label: D
options.text: They interact weakly with matter and are difficult to detect.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the IceCube neutrino telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect cosmic rays and their energies.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of neutrinos and their interactions with matter.

options.label: C
options.text: To observe the highest energy cosmic neutrinos ever seen.

options.label: D
options.text: To detect high-energy neutrinos and study the universe's most violent and energetic phenomena.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists detect neutrinos at the IceCube telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: By detecting the light emitted by the neutrino as it collides with an atom.

options.label: B
options.text: By detecting the sound waves produced by the neutrino as it collides with an atom.

options.label: C
options.text: By detecting the neutrino's magnetic field.

options.label: D
options.text: By detecting the charged particles produced by the neutrino as it collides with an atom, which then produce a cone of blue light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the photomultiplier tubes in the IceCube telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce the light that is emitted by the neutrino as it collides with an atom.

options.label: B
options.text: They detect the charged particles produced by the neutrino as it collides with an atom.

options.label: C
options.text: They amplify the signal of the neutrino as it collides with an atom.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not play a role in the detection of neutrinos.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of giving nicknames to the neutrinos detected at the IceCube telescope?

options.label: A
options.text: To commemorate the scientists who detected the neutrinos.

options.label: B
options.text: To give a personal touch to the neutrinos and make them more interesting.

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the neutrinos and track their properties.

options.label: D
options.text: To give nicknames to the neutrinos to make them more memorable and to highlight the rarity of their detection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the IceCube telescope in the field of astronomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the first telescope to detect neutrinos in the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the largest neutrino telescope in the world.

options.label: C
options.text: It has opened up a new field of astronomy, neutrino astronomy.

options.label: D
options.text: It has already observed the highest energy cosmic neutrinos ever seen and has opened up a new field of astronomy, neutrino astronomy.

multiple-choice.question: What can the neutrinos detected by the IceCube telescope tell us about the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: They can tell us about the composition of the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: They can tell us about the age of the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: They can tell us about the most violent and energetic phenomena in the universe, such as supermassive black holes and cosmic dynamos.

options.label: D
options.text: They can tell us about the properties of dark matter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of neutrino astronomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a well-established field of astronomy.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a new and rapidly developing field of astronomy.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a field that is still in its infancy.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a field that has just begun to reveal the secrets of the universe, with the IceCube telescope marking the beginning of this new era.

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: What's the difference between accuracy and precision? - Matt Anticole

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: She made a full recovery and was able to return to her normal life

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor's message to the world?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: The similarity in DNA and ribosomes between chloroplasts and mitochondria and ancient bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of eukaryotic cells to make new chloroplasts and mitochondria

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the two membranes surrounding chloroplasts and mitochondria?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide protection to the cell

options.label: B
options.text: They allow for the exchange of materials between the cell and the environment

options.label: C
options.text: The inner membrane contains lipids and proteins that were present in the ancient bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: The outer membrane is responsible for photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the result of the absorbing process of endosymbiotic theory?

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of complex organisms with combined abilities

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an organism that formed as a result of the absorbing process of endosymbiotic theory?
According to the transcript, what is the current best explanation of how complex cells evolved?
What is the significance of the endosymbiotic theory in explaining the origin of the vast variety of eukaryotic organisms?

options.label: A
options.text: It explains the formation of simple organisms

options.label: B
options.text: It explains the formation of complex organisms with combined abilities

options.label: C
options.text: It explains the formation of multicellular organisms

options.label: D
options.text: It explains the formation of single-celled organisms

title: History vs. Richard Nixon - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Which U.S. president resigned from office in 1974 due to the Watergate scandal?
What was the main reason President Nixon resigned from office?

options.label: A
options.text: He was facing a loss in the election.

options.label: B
options.text: He was ill and couldn't continue serving.

options.label: C
options.text: He was about to be impeached and didn't want the full extent of his crimes exposed.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to take a vacation.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Watergate scandal, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A peaceful protest against the Vietnam War.

options.label: B
options.text: A presidential campaign courted Southern voters through fear and resentment of the civil rights movement.

options.label: C
options.text: A guaranteed basic income for all American families.

options.label: D
options.text: A burglary at the Democratic National Committee headquarters to wiretap the offices and dig up dirt on opponents for the reelection campaign.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of President Nixon's foreign policy achievements, according to the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: Supporting the coup in Chile that replaced the democratically-elected President Allende with a brutal military dictator.

options.label: D
options.text: Normalizing ties with China, forging economic ties that continue today.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the Title IX amendment signed by President Nixon?

options.label: A
options.text: To lower the voting age to 18

options.label: C
options.text: To propose a guaranteed basic income for all American families

options.label: D
options.text: To ban gender-based discrimination in education

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of President Nixon's campaign, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: He won the election with a landslide victory.

options.label: B
options.text: He lost the election and was replaced by a new president.

options.label: C
options.text: He ended the Vietnam War immediately.

options.label: D
options.text: He protracted the war for four years, in which 20,000 more U.S. troops, and over a million more Vietnamese, died for nothing.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Logan Act of 1799, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A law that prohibits presidential candidates from interfering in foreign negotiations.

options.label: B
options.text: A law that requires presidential candidates to disclose their financial records.

options.label: C
options.text: A law that prohibits presidential candidates from campaigning on fear and resentment of the civil rights movement.

options.label: D
options.text: A law that requires presidential candidates to support comprehensive healthcare reform.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of President Nixon's environmental policies, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Supporting the coup in Chile that replaced the democratically-elected President Allende with a brutal military dictator.

options.label: D
options.text: Proposing the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency, and signing the National Environmental Policy Act into law.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Kent State shootings, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Four students were shot by the National Guard, and President Nixon was shocked and outraged.

options.label: B
options.text: Four students were shot by the National Guard, and President Nixon called them "bums" for protesting the Vietnam War.

options.label: C
options.text: No students were shot by the National Guard.

options.label: D
options.text: President Nixon ended the Vietnam War immediately.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main harm caused by President Nixon's actions, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: He broke a law or two, but what was the real harm compared to all he accomplished while in office?

options.label: B
options.text: Law-breaking and cover-ups threaten the very fabric the nation is built on.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a successful president who accomplished many things, but his legacy was tainted by the Watergate scandal.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a failed president who accomplished nothing, and his legacy was not affected by the Watergate scandal.

title: The history of museums - J. V. Maranto

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "museum"?

options.label: A
options.text: It comes from the Latin word for "temple"

options.label: B
options.text: It comes from the Greek word for "temple" or "mouseion"

options.label: C
options.text: It comes from the Greek word for "art"

options.label: D
options.text: It comes from the Greek word for "science"

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first curator of the first museum, which was created in 530 B.C. in what is now Iraq?

Who was the wealthy 17th-century naturalist, antiquarian, and physician who had one of the most notable Wunderkammers?
What was the name of the museum that Phineas T. Barnum started in New York City?
How did visitors typically access museums before they became open to the public?

options.label: B
options.text: By applying in writing prior to admission

multiple-choice.question: What institution was started in the 19th century to make objects available for study and research?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are too expensive and may bar admission to those who can't afford to satisfy their curiosity

options.label: B
options.text: That they are not open to the public

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the gift shop that the speaker mentions at the end of the tour?

options.label: B
options.text: The Gift Shop of Gift Shops
